Off The Deep End
It may seem superficial to select any one point
from an address such as Mr. Norman Thomas's last
Saturday, and to dwell upon it to the exclusion of
others. Rut from another standpoint it is a tribute
to the profoundness of his remarks that we should
find so much room for amplification in a single gesture. The phase of his talk that most impressed us
was his impatience with questioners who wanted to
know what the pacifist will do if America is invaded.
He pointed out that in every war in which she
has participated since 1812, America has been the
aggressor, no matter 'what her "moral" foundation,
and has not been subjected to invasion. He described
as "remote" the possibility that we ever will be invaded. And, directly, he said that organized refusal
to fight is the pacifist's only answer.
But pressed further by another inquisitor, he
lost patience and interrupted to say that unless this
generation realizes that there is some intermediate
weapon "between passive resistance and revolution as
a means of acquiring peace, we will be doomed." He
condemned hypothetizing as subversive to the immediate best interests of the pacifist cause.
His flare-up, we believe, is attributable to the
nature of his own convictions. His impatience was
that of a man who has gone as far as he can cautiously
and gropingly, and then leaped off into space. An
intolerance for the indecision of unconvinced youngsters is understandable in a man who has cut himself
irretrievably loose; who "cannot keep house with himself and sanction war"; who has committed himself
to the point where no amount of hypothesis could
possibly have any effect on his unalterable course.
The temporizing, bickering, and fatuous applauding of the audience during Mr. Thomas's session
aroused grave doubt as to the future of the pacifist
cause. Attention to the speaker was but casual, the
majority of the preponderantly female audience being
divided between silly old women who simpered,
clapped, and waved across the room indiscriminately,
and pseudo-intellectual girls who mostly lit murads
and gazed, enrapt, at the ceiling. The cool and calculated, yet impassioned oratory of one of the leading
speakers in the country- seemed to stop short of im'pressing a gross and unimaginative group; his "dynamic" returned to him void.
Sessions of that sort make us question whether
Mr. Thomas is not alone, with but few consorts, as
a prophet of a lost cause.

We're At It Again
In our last issue we again directed the attention
of our readers to the grotesque lack of equilibrium in
the organization of the faculty duties at the Hopkins.
We again dragged out the figures to show that of
twenty-three of the most prominent faculty members,
who are also national and international figures, only
two may be reached by the undergraduate through
the classroom. One of these professors requires that
only the ten best men in the class be admitted to his
course each year.

The out-and-out exclusiveness of these men who
are the very mainstays of an institution founded as
'a partnership of students and professors dedicated
to the joint search for truth is an anomaly of no
small imbort. Because we have been impressed that
herein lies possibly one of the impediments to
even greater accomplishments by Hopkins men we
have carefully and persistently kept it an open matter.
The President of the University evinces a sympathy
for our position but states that he must depend upon
the professors to see the point themselves and to voluntarily abandon their cloisters. That such lack of
cooperation should exist in a partnership of foregoing
description is also impressive. It makes us wonder
if the University might not be compared to the
whited sepulchre or hollow tree-trunk.
Without any intention of being dramatic about
our impressions, however, we have solicited from a
contributor himself, a member of the faculty, the
article which appears on this page today under the
heading of "Top-Heavy Hopkins". We recommend
it to the thoughtful attention of the faculty and administration, in particular, and also to any students
who might possibly be blessed with an idea concerning the situation.

IT IS just a little over sixty years
since the death of Johns Hopkins, Baltimore merchant prince and friend of
young men. I call him the friend of
young men because the appellation is perfectly true and because it has a present
pathetic significance which inspires this
article.
There is nothing in the will of Johns
Hopkins which can be wrenched into the
meaning that he desired the undergraduate departments of his university neglected for the benefit of the higher
schools. And yet this is what is actually
taking place, at least in one of the colleges at Homewood. I have contacts at
the University which enable me to observe the undercurrents of change which
flow through that institution, to observe
the attitude both of students and faculty;
and I cannot help feeling disheartened at
what is revealed to me.

THERE IS said to be little college
spirit at Hopkins. No one who is familiar with the campus will deny this accusation, least of all the students themselves. The explanation of this condition
is not far to seek. There is prevalent
among the undergraduates a feeling of
indifference which, in the case of the
keener minds, mounts to indignation and
resentment, and which springs from the
attitude of patronage practised by most
of the faculty. With a few notable exceptions, these latter gentlemen consider
that their undergraduate courses are
bread and butter affairs which are necessary as a means of commanding a salary,
but are to be escaped from as soon as
possible so that attention can be paid to
the graduate students. If a freshman enrolls in the College of Arts and Sciences,
hoping to come under the tutelage of a
great name, he will be disappointed, for
in almost every case the "big" men of the
faculty have very little to do with classes
in the College of Arts and Sciences. Only
a casual examination of the announcement issued for this college proves this
statement. If a student desires the guidance of a Lovejoy, or a Hollander, or a
Malone, or a Chinard, or a Reed, he
must indicate graduate leanings in his last
years and then perhaps may be accepted
in the pro-graduate courses given by
these men.
BUT THIS is by no means the worst
of the situation. Some of the instructors
inflicted upon the first-year man would
not be tolerated in any other university
of a similar rank. Well-meaning though
he may be, capable as he may demonstrate himself in his research, a graduate
student pursuing his work toward an
M.A. or a Ph.D. is not usually an efficient instructor. In most cases his mind
is on other things, pursuing, let us say,
the third layer of allegory in the fifth
book of The Faerie Queene; in far too
many cases he lacks experience altogether
in teaching. And when is a good instructor more needed than by a bewildered freshman? He comes to a new environn*nt dazed by the difference of
things, in most cases eager and willing,
though dumb, and if ever he needs a
sympathetic, experienced hand to guide
him into profitable channels of behavior
and thought, it is then. A most capable
and understanding registrar does all that
he can. So do the various Deans. But
their time is limited. Obviously, five pr
six men can not watch and guide eight
hundred through their period of Storm
and Stress!
SO THE undergraduates are assigned
to "advisers". Now, if John Smith is
lucky enough to get a Hubbard, a Miles,
a Lancaster, or a Secrist, he is all set
for better things; but if he gets a younger

man or a disinterested older man who is
bored by the thought of youngsters—and
this does occur and not infreqbently—
he is all set in the other direction. There
are men on the faculty who realize this
situation and do all that they can individually' to correct it. I know of three
of the older men,, connected with Hopkins through a long period of years,
whose office doors are always open and
who are never too busy to extend a helping and kindly hand. And I know of
other faculty members—important personages, too, whose fame has been bruited
abroad—who do not possess the cqmmon
courtesy to ask a young man to sit down
when he ventures trembling into their
sacred grottoes. I confess to a righteous
indignation, which boiled over and left
me weak, when I passed through the hallowed halls of Gilman last week beneath
the sacred portraits of Remsen and Osler
and heard, from the depths of a neighboring office, the what-the-hell-do-youwant tones which welcomed a diffident
first year student. Gruffness too often
seems a concomitant of greatness — at
Hopkins.

Off The Deep End
It may seem superficial to select any one point
from an address such as Mr. Norman Thomas's last
Saturday, and to dwell upon it to the exclusion of
others. Rut from another standpoint it is a tribute
to the profoundness of his remarks that we should
find so much room for amplification in a single gesture. The phase of his talk that most impressed us
was his impatience with questioners who wanted to
know what the pacifist will do if America is invaded.
He pointed out that in every war in which she
has participated since 1812, America has been the
aggressor, no matter 'what her "moral" foundation,
and has not been subjected to invasion. He described
as "remote" the possibility that we ever will be invaded. And, directly, he said that organized refusal
to fight is the pacifist's only answer.
But pressed further by another inquisitor, he
lost patience and interrupted to say that unless this
generation realizes that there is some intermediate
weapon "between passive resistance and revolution as
a means of acquiring peace, we will be doomed." He
condemned hypothetizing as subversive to the immediate best interests of the pacifist cause.
His flare-up, we believe, is attributable to the
nature of his own convictions. His impatience was
that of a man who has gone as far as he can cautiously
and gropingly, and then leaped off into space. An
intolerance for the indecision of unconvinced youngsters is understandable in a man who has cut himself
irretrievably loose; who "cannot keep house with himself and sanction war"; who has committed himself
to the point where no amount of hypothesis could
possibly have any effect on his unalterable course.
The temporizing, bickering, and fatuous applauding of the audience during Mr. Thomas's session
aroused grave doubt as to the future of the pacifist
cause. Attention to the speaker was but casual, the
majority of the preponderantly female audience being
divided between silly old women who simpered,
clapped, and waved across the room indiscriminately,
and pseudo-intellectual girls who mostly lit murads
and gazed, enrapt, at the ceiling. The cool and calculated, yet impassioned oratory of one of the leading
speakers in the country- seemed to stop short of im'pressing a gross and unimaginative group; his "dynamic" returned to him void.
Sessions of that sort make us question whether
Mr. Thomas is not alone, with but few consorts, as
a prophet of a lost cause.

We're At It Again
In our last issue we again directed the attention
of our readers to the grotesque lack of equilibrium in
the organization of the faculty duties at the Hopkins.
We again dragged out the figures to show that of
twenty-three of the most prominent faculty members,
who are also national and international figures, only
two may be reached by the undergraduate through
the classroom. One of these professors requires that
only the ten best men in the class be admitted to his
course each year.

The out-and-out exclusiveness of these men who
are the very mainstays of an institution founded as
'a partnership of students and professors dedicated
to the joint search for truth is an anomaly of no
small imbort. Because we have been impressed that
herein lies possibly one of the impediments to
even greater accomplishments by Hopkins men we
have carefully and persistently kept it an open matter.
The President of the University evinces a sympathy
for our position but states that he must depend upon
the professors to see the point themselves and to voluntarily abandon their cloisters. That such lack of
cooperation should exist in a partnership of foregoing
description is also impressive. It makes us wonder
if the University might not be compared to the
whited sepulchre or hollow tree-trunk.
Without any intention of being dramatic about
our impressions, however, we have solicited from a
contributor himself, a member of the faculty, the
article which appears on this page today under the
heading of "Top-Heavy Hopkins". We recommend
it to the thoughtful attention of the faculty and administration, in particular, and also to any students
who might possibly be blessed with an idea concerning the situation.
